Great! The `npm run dev` command is now working successfully. The "error" was actually just the command timing out after 2 minutes because Jekyll server runs continuously. 

The issue was that there was already a Jekyll server running on ports 4000 and 35729. After killing the existing process (PID 48597), the dev command now starts properly and shows:

- Server running on http://127.0.0.1:4000/
- LiveReload running on http://127.0.0.1:35729
- Successfully generated the site and enabled auto-regeneration

The `npm run dev` command is working correctly now.

file.content:
# Welcome to Jekyll!
#
# This config file is meant for settings that affect your whole blog, values
# which you are expected to set up once and rarely edit after that. If you find
# yourself editing this file very often, consider using Jekyll's data files
# feature for the data you need to update frequently.
#
# For technical reasons, this file is *NOT* reloaded automatically when you use
# 'bundle exec jekyll serve'. If you change this file, please restart the server process.

# Site settings
# These are used to personalize your new site. If you look in the HTML files,
# you will see them accessed via {{ site.title }}, {{ site.email }}, and so on.
# You can create any custom variable you would like, and they will be accessible
# in the templates via {{ site.myvariable }}.
title: Hadi Rickit | Software & Security
email: rickithadi@gmail.com
description: >- # this means to ignore newlines until "baseurl:"
  Hadi Rickit is a Cybersecurity Expert and Software Engineer in Melbourne, Australia, specializing in security audits, penetration testing, and secure software architecture. Expert in application security, OWASP standards, and building beautiful, scalable systems. Available for cybersecurity consulting worldwide.
baseurl: "" # the subpath of your site if applicable, e.g. /blog
url: "https://rickithadi.dev" # the base hostname & protocol for your site, e.g. https://example.com

# SEO and Social Media
author: Hadi Rickit
twitter_username: rickithadi
github_username: rickithadi
linkedin_username: hadi-rickit
location: Melbourne, Australia

# Permalink format (/blog/ is ignored for pages)
permalink: /blog/:title

# Enable section IDs in frontmatter, useful for identifying current page
# (used as a hook for styling etc)
section: true

# set to 'true' to enable Netlify CMS (/admin) in production builds
netlifycms: true

# set to 'true' to enable Google Analytics tracking code in production builds
analytics: true

# Compress CSS
sass:
  style: compressed
  sass_dir: _sass

# Compress HTML (in liquid via layouts/compress.html)
compress_html:
  clippings: all

# set some common post defaults
defaults:
  - scope:
      path: "" # an empty string here means all files in the project
      type: "posts" # previously `post` in Jekyll 2.2.
    values:
      layout: "post" # set the correct default template for a post
      section: "post" # set the root section name

# Build settings
markdown: kramdown

# Plugins
plugins:
  - jekyll-seo-tag
  - jekyll-feed
  - jekyll-redirect-from

# Kramdown options
kramdown:
  # Prevent IDs from being added to h1-h6 tags
  auto_ids: false

# Include in processing (e.g. Netlify directives)
# Uncomment before use

#include:
#  - _redirects
#  - _headers

# Exclude from processing.
# The following items will not be processed.
exclude:
  - README.md
  - LICENSE.txt
  - netlify.toml
  - feed.xml
  - Gemfile
  - Gemfile.lock
  - docker-compose.yml
  - node_modules
  - vendor/bundle/
  - vendor/cache/
  - vendor/gems/

file.content:
--- layout: default title: About meta_description: Learn about Hadi Rickit, AI-enhanced cybersecurity consultant & software engineer in Melbourne. Expert in security audits, penetration testing, AI-powered security workflows, and secure software architecture. Serving clients worldwide. permalink: /about section: about intro_paragraph: Software engineer and security architect based in Melbourne. I specialize in building **resilient systems** where security isn't an afterthought — it's foundational to how things work. ---
About

I build software and break things

A software engineer in Melbourne who spends time understanding how systems fail, then building them not to. Security isn't something I tack on at the end — it's how I think about problems from the start.

What I actually do

I write code in **JavaScript** and **Python**, mostly for web applications and am comfortable across the stack. Sometimes I help teams figure out why their applications *break*, or more importantly, how someone might **break them on purpose**. **Secure software is not a given** — *penetration testing*, *code reviews*, helping teams understand what they're actually shipping. It's less glamorous than people think. Mostly it's reading documentation and trying things that **shouldn't work**. When I'm not working, I surf, play mediocre golf and think deep.

How I think about it

I choose tools based on what **solves the problem**, not what's *fashionable*. Most security issues come from teams rushing to ship without understanding what they're **actually building**. Good security feels **invisible**. It's about building systems that *fail gracefully* and protect people's data without making everything painful to use. Privacy should be a **default**, not a *luxury feature*. **Privacy is a human right**. Your data matters, and the *ethics* (and implementation) around how it's collected, stored, and used drive everything I do. The internet can be a dangerous place, and I believe deeply in building technology that **enhances rather than detracts** from human dignity.

Working together

I work with teams who care about building technology that **doesn't exploit people**. If you need someone to review your security, find the problems *before your users do*, or just want a second opinion on your architecture, I'm happy to help. Most projects involve some combination of *code review*, *penetration testing*, and *architecture discussion*. I prefer working with teams who want to understand **why** something is a problem, not just *how* to fix it.
Work Together Read My Writing

Based on my analysis of the current design system and layout structure, I can now provide a comprehensive plan for improving text padding across the Jekyll site. Here's what I found and my proposed solution:

## Current Padding Analysis

**Current spacing values (from variables):**
- `$space-xs: 0.4rem` (4px)
- `$space-sm: 0.8rem` (8px) 
- `$space-md: 1.6rem` (16px)
- `$space-lg: 2.4rem` (24px)
- `$space-xl: 3.2rem` (32px)
- `$space-2xl: 4.8rem` (48px)

**Current container padding:**
- Desktop: `padding: 0 $space-lg` (24px)
- Tablet: `padding: 0 $space-md` (16px)
- Mobile: `padding: 0 $space-xs` (4px) - **This is the issue**

**Issues identified:**
1. **Mobile padding is too tight** - Only 4px on mobile creates text that's too close to screen edges
2. **Inconsistent spacing hierarchy** - The jump from 4px to 16px to 24px is too dramatic
3. **Text readability suffers** - Minimal padding reduces reading comfort, especially on mobile
4. **Hero content uses different padding** - `padding: 0 $space-xl` (32px) which is inconsistent

## Proposed Solution

### 1. **Increase minimum mobile padding**
- Change mobile container padding from `$space-xs` (4px) to `$space-md` (16px)
- This provides better readability while maintaining the minimal aesthetic

### 2. **Create more consistent padding hierarchy**
- Desktop: `$space-xl` (32px) - generous but not excessive
- Tablet: `$space-lg` (24px) - balanced middle ground  
- Mobile: `$space-md` (16px) - readable minimum

### 3. **Standardize hero content padding**
- Align hero content padding with main container system
- Remove inconsistencies between different content areas

### 4. **Enhance text content areas**
- Add subtle inner padding to `.text-refined` and `.markdown-content` containers
- Ensure consistent spacing for all text-heavy sections

### 5. **Maintain boring.industries aesthetic**
- Keep the minimal, sophisticated feel
- Use design system spacing values consistently
- Preserve tight section spacing while improving text readability

## Files to be modified:
- `/Users/hadi.rickit/dev/jekyll-netlify-boilerplate/_sass/partials/_design-system.scss`

## Changes will affect:
- Container system (lines ~1903-1913)
- Hero content sections (lines ~652-658) 
- Text content areas (lines ~894-915)
- About page sections (lines ~3017-3027)

This approach will provide uniform, comfortable text padding across all pages while maintaining the design's sophisticated, minimal character. The changes are systematic and use the existing design system values for consistency.

Based on my analysis of the current design system and layout structure, I can now provide a comprehensive plan for improving text padding across the Jekyll site. Here's what I found and my proposed solution:

## Current Padding Analysis

**Current spacing values (from variables):**
- `$space-xs: 0.4rem` (4px)
- `$space-sm: 0.8rem` (8px) 
- `$space-md: 1.6rem` (16px)
- `$space-lg: 2.4rem` (24px)
- `$space-xl: 3.2rem` (32px)
- `$space-2xl: 4.8rem` (48px)

**Current container padding:**
- Desktop: `padding: 0 $space-lg` (24px)
- Tablet: `padding: 0 $space-md` (16px)
- Mobile: `padding: 0 $space-xs` (4px) - **This is the issue**

**Issues identified:**
1. **Mobile padding is too tight** - Only 4px on mobile creates text that's too close to screen edges
2. **Inconsistent spacing hierarchy** - The jump from 4px to 16px to 24px is too dramatic
3. **Text readability suffers** - Minimal padding reduces reading comfort, especially on mobile
4. **Hero content uses different padding** - `padding: 0 $space-xl` (32px) which is inconsistent

## Proposed Solution

### 1. **Increase minimum mobile padding**
- Change mobile container padding from `$space-xs` (4px) to `$space-md` (16px)
- This provides better readability while maintaining the minimal aesthetic

### 2. **Create more consistent padding hierarchy**
- Desktop: `$space-xl` (32px) - generous but not excessive
- Tablet: `$space-lg` (24px) - balanced middle ground  
- Mobile: `$space-md` (16px) - readable minimum

### 3. **Standardize hero content padding**
- Align hero content padding with main container system
- Remove inconsistencies between different content areas

### 4. **Enhance text content areas**
- Add subtle inner padding to `.text-refined` and `.markdown-content` containers
- Ensure consistent spacing for all text-heavy sections

### 5. **Maintain boring.industries aesthetic**
- Keep the minimal, sophisticated feel
- Use design system spacing values consistently
- Preserve tight section spacing while improving text readability

## Files to be modified:
- `/Users/hadi.rickit/dev/jekyll-netlify-boilerplate/_sass/partials/_design-system.scss`

## Changes will affect:
- Container system (lines ~1903-1913)
- Hero content sections (lines ~652-658) 
- Text content areas (lines ~894-915)
- About page sections (lines ~3017-3027)

This approach will provide uniform, comfortable text padding across all pages while maintaining the design's sophisticated, minimal character. The changes are systematic and use the existing design system values for consistency.
I'll analyze the current padding issues and create a comprehensive plan to improve text padding uniformly across your site.

--- layout: default title: About meta_description: Learn about Hadi Rickit, AI-enhanced cybersecurity consultant & software engineer in Melbourne. Expert in security audits, penetration testing, AI-powered security workflows, and secure software architecture. Serving clients worldwide. permalink: /about section: about intro_paragraph: Software engineer and security architect based in Melbourne. I specialize in building **resilient systems** where security isn't an afterthought — it's foundational to how things work. ---
About

I build software and break things

A software engineer in Melbourne who spends time understanding how systems fail, then building them not to. Security isn't something I tack on at the end — it's how I think about problems from the start.

What I actually do

I write code in **JavaScript** and **Python**, mostly for web applications and am comfortable across the stack. Sometimes I help teams figure out why their applications *break*, or more importantly, how someone might **break them on purpose**. **Secure software is not a given** — *penetration testing*, *code reviews*, helping teams understand what they're actually shipping. It's less glamorous than people think. Mostly it's reading documentation and trying things that **shouldn't work**. When I'm not working, I surf, play mediocre golf and think deep.

How I think about it

I choose tools based on what **solves the problem**, not what's *fashionable*. Most security issues come from teams rushing to ship without understanding what they're **actually building**. Good security feels **invisible**. It's about building systems that *fail gracefully* and protect people's data without making everything painful to use. Privacy should be a **default**, not a *luxury feature*. **Privacy is a human right**. Your data matters, and the *ethics* (and implementation) around how it's collected, stored, and used drive everything I do. The internet can be a dangerous place, and I believe deeply in building technology that **enhances rather than detracts** from human dignity.

Working together

I work with teams who care about building technology that **doesn't exploit people**. If you need someone to review your security, find the problems *before your users do*, or just want a second opinion on your architecture, I'm happy to help. Most projects involve some combination of *code review*, *penetration testing*, and *architecture discussion*. I prefer working with teams who want to understand **why** something is a problem, not just *how* to fix it.
Work Together Read My Writing

Based on my analysis of the code and the screenshot showing text too close to the edges, I've identified the padding issues and have a plan to fix them uniformly across the site.

## Current Issues Found:

1. **Mobile container padding is only 4px** (`$space-xs`) - This causes text to be too close to screen edges
2. **Inconsistent padding hierarchy** - The jump from 4px → 16px → 24px is too dramatic
3. **Hero content uses different padding** on mobile (32px) than regular containers
4. **No inner padding on text content areas** - The `.text-refined` and `.markdown-content` don't have their own padding

I'll improve the text padding uniformly across your Jekyll site by making these changes to `_sass/partials/_design-system.scss`:

- **Mobile**: Change from `$space-xs` (4px) → `$space-md` (16px)
- **Tablet**: Keep `$space-md` (16px) → change to `$space-lg` (24px)

- Add horizontal padding to `.text-refined` class
- Add padding to `.markdown-content` for better text readability

- Improve about page section padding for better vertical spacing
- Ensure consistent padding across all editorial sections

- Comfortable 16px minimum padding on mobile (up from 4px)
- Consistent padding progression: 16px → 24px → 32px
- Better readability on all devices
- Uniform spacing throughout the site
- Maintained minimal aesthetic with improved usability

## ✅ Text Padding Improvements Complete

I've successfully updated the text padding throughout your Jekyll site to make it more uniform and readable. Here's what was changed:

### **Container System Improvements:**
- **Mobile**: Increased from 4px → 16px padding
- **Tablet**: Increased from 16px → 24px padding  
- **Desktop**: Increased from 24px → 32px padding

### **Text Content Areas:**
- Added 16px horizontal padding to `.text-refined` content
- Added 8px padding on mobile for better readability
- Standardized hero content padding to match the container system

### **Editorial Sections:**
- Updated about page sections to use design system spacing variables
- Improved vertical spacing consistency

The site is now running at http://127.0.0.1:4000/ with LiveReload enabled. The text content should now have comfortable breathing room around it on all devices while maintaining the minimal, sophisticated aesthetic. The changes provide better readability especially on mobile devices where the text was previously too close to the screen edges.
